all_paragraphs: Vcpkg is a great package manager for C++ provided by Microsoft. It greatly simplifies the acquisition and installation of third-party libraries on Windows, Linux, and macOS.

To start using it with your C++ projects you first need to clone the repository onto your local machine. The repository is located here. When you’re cloning, it’s important to choose a folder that will be easy to find on the path. Something like C:\dev\vcpkg. From a command prompt you would do this:

Let’s say you want to install OpenCV4 on your computer so you can integrate it into your C++ programs. You would do something like this:

The triplet describes the architecture and environment you want to install the package for. If this is the first package you have installed, vcpkg will download and install a compatible cmake which it will then use to build packages. Once it’s done that it will then work out all the dependencies for opencv4 and build them first. Finally it will build the opencv4 package and store it in the package cache. Once you’ve installed a package you can then use it within your C+ projects.

Creating your own package is quite straightforward. I’m going to give an example here of one I created for the TensforFlow C API (see https://www.tensorflow.org/install/lang_c) using the pre-packaged files created by the TensorFlow team. From a command prompt do the following:

Here you’ve given your package the name tensorflow-c-gpu and told it where to download the zip file from and what you’ll call it locally. Issuing this command will create a cmake file that is used to build your package. In our example this file will be ports\tensorflow-c-gpu\tensorflow-c-gpu.cmake. Every package also needs a metadata file called vcpkg.json. This needs to be created in the same folder as the cmake file. Let’s create a console app that uses this package. In Visual Studio create a C++ Console App. I’ve called mine TfConsole. I’ll include a link for the source at the end of this article.

Change the Use Vcpkg Manifest option to be Yes as shown here.
If you don’t see the Vcpkg option in the Configuration Properties that means you haven’t yet run the “integrate install” command shown earlier.
You’ll also need to add the tensorflow.lib library as input to the linker:
In the main.cpp we’ll do a simple include of the tensorflow C API and then use that to show the Tensorflow version number:
One important thing to note is that the package contains the GPU version of TensorFlow 2.3.0 so you must have CUDA 10.1 installed on your machine to run this.
If everything is successful you will see the version number on your console output. It should 2.3.0.

I think the vcpkg manager from Microsoft is a great package manager and more and more packages are being added to it. I’ve also shown you here how to add your own, which can be quite straightforward once you know what you’re doing. I’m planning on doing a series of articles about using Machine Learning models in production in a Windows environment. It will cover a Windows front end (it will be a WPF C# desktop app) using various different backends. One of the backends will be using the tensorflow C API — which turns out to be pretty hardcore as there’s no documentation on it and very few examples of usage! But it’s also super quick (it does inference quicker than my Python code).
